answer_html: \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(2)=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}\) and this also converges by the p-series test. Thus, the interval of convergence is \(\color{blue}-4 \leq x \leq 2\)
answer_latex:
$\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(2)=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}$  and this also converges by the \emph{p}-series test. Thus,
the interval of convergence is $\color{blue}-4 \leq x \leq 2$
hints_html:
Try applying a series convergence test to determine which values of \(x\) will make the series converge. Which series test works best in this situation (that is, a series with a variable x?)

Use the ratio test.

Don’t forget to check endpoints!
hints_latex:
Try applying a series convergence test to determine which values of $x$
will make the series converge. Which series test works best in this
situation (that is, a series with a variable \emph{x}?)
hints_raw:
Try applying a series convergence test to determine which values of <math>x</math> will make the series converge. Which series test works best in this situation (that is, a series with a variable ''x''?)
Use the ratio test.
Don't forget to check endpoints!
question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
To determine the interval of convergence, we apply the ratio test. Let

\[\begin{aligned} a_{k}(x) = \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}.\end{aligned}\]

To determine the interval of convergence, we must find the values of \(x\) such that the value of the limit below is less than 1 (and then we need to check the endpoints). Evaluating gives

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{a_{k+1}(x)}{a_{k}(x)} \right| &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{(x+1)^{2k+2}}{(k+1)^{2}9^{k+1}} \div \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \right|\\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{(x+1)^{2k+2}}{(k+1)^{2}9^{k+1}}\frac{k^{2}9^{k}}{(x+1)^{2k}} \right| \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{k}{k+1}\right)^{2}(x+1)^{2} \right| \\ &= \left|\frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} \right| \\ &= \frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9}\end{aligned}\]

where we drop the absolute value signs, since \([(x+1)^{2}]/9\) is always positive.

Now, when the above limit is less than one, we have:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} &< 1 \\ (x+1)^{2} &< 9\\ -3 < x+1 &< 3\\ -4 < x &< 2.\end{aligned}\]

Similarly, we know what when \(\frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} > 1\) that is, when \(x < -4\) and when \(x > 2\), we have that the series diverges. So all that is left is to check the two endpoints. When \(x = -4\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(-4) &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-4+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-3)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{9^{k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

and this converges by the p-series test. Similarly, when \(x=2\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(2) &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(2+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(3)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{9^{k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

and this also converges by the p-series test. Thus, the interval of convergence is \(\color{blue}-4 \leq x \leq 2\)
sols_latex:
To determine the interval of convergence, we apply the ratio test. Let

\begin{align*}
a_{k}(x) = \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}.
\end{align*} To determine the interval
of convergence, we must find the values of $x$ such that the value of
the limit below is less than 1 (and then we need to check the
endpoints). Evaluating gives

\begin{align*}
\lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{a_{k+1}(x)}{a_{k}(x)} \right| 
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{(x+1)^{2k+2}}{(k+1)^{2}9^{k+1}} \div \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \right|\\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{(x+1)^{2k+2}}{(k+1)^{2}9^{k+1}}\frac{k^{2}9^{k}}{(x+1)^{2k}} \right| \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{k}{k+1}\right)^{2}(x+1)^{2} \right| \\
&= \left|\frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} \right| \\
&= \frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9}
\end{align*} where we drop the absolute value signs, since
$[(x+1)^{2}]/9$ is always positive.

Now, when the above limit is less than one, we have:

\begin{align*}
\frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} &< 1 \\
(x+1)^{2} &< 9\\
-3 < x+1 &< 3\\
-4 < x &< 2.
\end{align*} Similarly, we know what when $\frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} > 1$
that is, when $x < -4$ and when $x > 2$, we have that the series
diverges. So all that is left is to check the two endpoints. When
$x = -4$, we have

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(-4) &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-4+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-3)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{9^{k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}
\end{align*} and this converges by the \emph{p}-series test. Similarly,
when $x=2$, we have

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(2) &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(2+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(3)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{9^{k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}
\end{align*} and this also converges by the \emph{p}-series test. Thus,
the interval of convergence is $\color{blue}-4 \leq x \leq 2$
sols_raw:
To determine the interval of convergence, we apply the <b>ratio test</b>. Let 
:<math>
a_{k}(x) = \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}.
</math>
To determine the interval of convergence, we must find the values of <math>x</math> such that the value of the limit below is less than 1 (and then we need to check the endpoints). Evaluating gives
:<math>
\begin{align}
\lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{a_{k+1}(x)}{a_{k}(x)} \right| 
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{(x+1)^{2k+2}}{(k+1)^{2}9^{k+1}} \div \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \right|\\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{(x+1)^{2k+2}}{(k+1)^{2}9^{k+1}}\frac{k^{2}9^{k}}{(x+1)^{2k}} \right| \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left|\frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{k}{k+1}\right)^{2}(x+1)^{2} \right| \\
&= \left|\frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} \right| \\
&= \frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9}
\end{align}
</math>
where we drop the absolute value signs, since <math>[(x+1)^{2}]/9</math> is always positive.

Now, when the above limit is less than one, we have:
:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} &< 1 \\
(x+1)^{2} &< 9\\
-3 < x+1 &< 3\\
-4 < x &< 2.
\end{align}
</math>
Similarly, we know what when <math> \frac{(x+1)^{2}}{9} > 1 </math> that is, when <math> x < -4 </math> and when <math> x > 2 </math>, we have that the series diverges. So all that is left is to check the two endpoints. When <math> x = -4 </math>, we have
:<math>
\begin{align}
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(-4) &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-4+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-3)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{9^{k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}\\
\end{align}
</math>
and this converges by the ''p''-series test. Similarly, when <math> x=2 </math>, we have
:<math>
\begin{align}
\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_{k}(2) &= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(2+1)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}} \\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(3)^{2k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{9^{k}}{k^{2}9^{k}}\\
&= \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{k^{2}}\\
\end{align}
</math>
and this also converges by the ''p''-series test. 
<font style="color:blue;">Thus, the interval of convergence is <math>\color{blue}-4 \leq x \leq 2</math></font>
statement_html:
Find the interval of convergence of the following series:

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^2 9^k}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Find the interval of convergence of the following series:

:<math>
\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{(x+1)^{2k}}{k^2 9^k}
</math>
